@AnkHit! *If I am understanding  correctly your murder argument then you are saying those who are responsible for the death of someone are punished, and those who are not responsible are not punished. Which I agree with.  It has been what I was trying to say in my previous comments as well.

@AnkHit! *I would not call that an assumption, it's an interpretation, which is not really something one can stop from doing. Now, I did not try to refuse to continue the argument either, if that is different from ending it, I had asked a question and you had claimed it was fallacious which I disagreed with and we we areguing about that I believe. If you had said you felt forced to answer or that you had felt uncomfortable answering for personal reasons I would not have tried to know more.*I still do not understand the flat earth argument however, are you saying that because those who believe that the earth is flat might be wrong then I should be wrong too? Even though I never claimed the earth was flat? I fail to see how this relates to this conversation at all.

@AnkHit! -force one to answer would be making them face legal consequences. They are given the choice of either answering a question or going to jail (for example), the parallel in our current situation in this conversation would be each time you ask me a question I would have the choice of either answering it or not answering it (notice the parallel here) and you would be free think whatever you want based on that.* I have thought that the flat earth was just some sort of example, I now have a hard time seeing how that would constitute a point, a clarification on how this relates to this conversation would help too.

@AnkHit! *I do not see how "not continuing the discussion" and "ending the discussion" are different statements so I would like clarification on this point.*In the court, a judge normally has the control over the situation and judges whether each side has to answer what question, in a conversation or a debate however, there is no such authority and therefore, to keep the integrity of the debate one side would answer the questions of the other (each would have a dedicated amount of time to ask their questions) whether they judge the reasoning that sprouts from these questions to be fallacious or not. They would then proceed to attack the point made and not the question itself.* I do not see how an act of assumption would be considered misconduct as assumption is a a thinking process that every person is subject to.* You have every right to insist I answer one question or another but it is unlikely that that would change the result of you query.*The means the a legal setting would use to

@AnkHit! -can go as far as a period of jail time, the parallel in our situation can be made by saying that if I refuse to answer one of your questions, then you are free to assume whatever you want from that, but in both cases one cannot be forced and have the choice of either answering/testifying or facing the consequences.

@AnkHit!* I do not remember saying I would end the discussion in case you did not answer, in case you think I did then I might have misspoke. I recall saying on multiple occasions that if you had personal reasons for not wanting to answer any of my questions, then you were free to say so and we could move on to something else as I have no intention on forcing you or anyone else to do something they would not be comfortable with.*Now, as I stated before with the gun example or in any accidental death situation. One would not be charged with the death itself, but with th negligence that caused it (if they are able to prove there were no prior intent), and in the case in which they commited no act of negligence, then the person would be able to walk away free of charge. Now, with the witness being forced to answer a question part, there seems to be a misunderstanding as what I meant was that a witness can choose not to answer and face the consequences of that, consequences which sometimes

@AnkHit! I  did not intend for you to feel forced to answer my question, as I said before, you are absolutely free to avoid answering it if you have personal reasons that push you not to (Though I disagree that it would lead to a fallacy but that is not really a matter of importance). If one is not conviced that the earth is round then that is there personal belief and I respect their right to hold whatever personal belief they wish to hold, no matter how absurd other might consider it. If one thinks the earth is flat, cubic or round, and are capable of providing valid proof for their claim, then I would be more than happy to consider adopting that belief myself. You contest my liberty to remain silent about certain subject, a point on which I disagree with, as I believe no one should be forced to disclose any information they are not comfortable sharing.

@AnkHit! I do not see why a definition I put out would need my personal intake to function, as the definition does not contain my personal intake itself. Now, to go back to the other subject, here is an extract about wrongful death lawsuits: "To seek damages in a wrongful death or survivor’s claim, you must prove liability. It may seem pretty straightforward, but when it comes to motor vehicle accidents, there may be several parties who hold financial liability. In some circumstances, you may have a case against multiple negligent parties." The family of the deceased had the right to file a wrongful death lawsuit in all cases, but has to be able to prove the other driver's liability, or the negligence he might be responsible of, for example drunk driving, or speeding, or failing to stop at a red light and so on.

@AnkHit! No, the official report would depend on the specific case, a common case of punishable negligence would be driving under the influence, a bigger case of negligence would be an employer ignoring security measures unintentionally causing the death of their employees, this would be severely punished.  A case not involving intent would be, for example, would be a "Perioperative mortality", sometimes surgeons make mistakes during their operation, mistakes that might directly or indirectly lead to the patient's death, the case is then investigated to make sure there was no intent to murder or negligence from the surgical team. If neither of this is found then the surgeon is not charged.
